column2: Rich in indigenous history. Aboriginal Land Trusts in or near the Beetaloo Sub-basin include Wubalawun, Mangarrayi, Murranji, Alawa, Gurungu, Marlinja, Dillinya, Karlantijpa and Mambaliya Rrumburriya Wuyaliya.
The Beetaloo Sub-basin is rich in natural shale and tight gas, and the broader area is important to a range of local plant and animal species.
Geology of the Beetaloo Sub-basin: A digital model

Ever wondered what lay beneath your feet? [newline][newline]This digital model of the Beetaloo Sub-basin in the Northern Territory will show you the geological layers deep underground â€“ what they are composed of, how big they are and where they sit in relation to other layers, such as limestone and groundwater layers. [newline][newline]Move the model, zoom in and out, click on the animations and read the descriptions to learn more.[newline][newline]The Overview helps locate and broadly describe the Beetaloo region within Australia's Northern Territory.[newline][newline]The Region level provides insights into the main population centres and prominant natural water features within the Beetaloo region.[newline][newline]The Geology of the region is then identified and examined from a historical perspective.[newline][newline]Finally, a Deep Dive is provided into the individual layers that comprise the Beetaloo Sub-basin.
